P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Tucker Carlson)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
Show More

Q.title: Will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers.
If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as at their discretion
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will Tucker Carlson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election AND will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following events occur: a.) Tucker Carlson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, AND b.) Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers.
If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as at their discretion
Show More

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Tucker Carlson)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, saying at a rally in March 2022, "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before". Early polling for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of June 2022), though Fox News producers have called him "the future of the Republican Party". DeSantis is a frequent second-place favorite in polling behind Trump.
Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; in April 2022, when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".
Show More

Q.title: Will Tesla become the largest car company in the world (by sales) before 2035?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Tesla Motors is the largest car producer in the world at any point before January 1, 2035, according to global car sales data from the International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers.
If data from OICA is not available during this period, Metaculus may select an alternative credible source of data, or resolve as at their discretion
Show More

metadata.background_info:
While Tesla is already a very large automobile company based on market capitalisation, a lot of that market capitalisation is based on expectations of the future. As of the writing of this question, Tesla is losing money and selling significantly less cars than even the 20th largest auto-company in the world. Yet, the expectations that have been set for Tesla by Elon Musk would probably require Tesla to sell more cars than any other company on the planet while maintaining large profit-margins.
In order to ramp-up production from approx. 100,000 to 500,000 or 1,000,000 cars a year, Tesla has created the Model 3, its first mass market car. Regrettably, Tesla has had trouble producing the Model 3 and production of the car can be tracked here. It is likely that Tesla's total vehicle production must exceed 10 million in order for it to become the world's largest car company. Yet, given its financial situation, there is a risk that the company goes bankrupt before that happens.

reasons: Political and economic landscapes are often intertwined. If Tucker Carlson, a prominent media personality with strong opinions on various economic policies, becomes the Republican nominee and potentially the President, his policies could significantly impact the automotive industry, including companies like Tesla.

Carlson's stance on environmental regulations, trade policies, and subsidies for electric vehicles could either benefit or hinder Tesla's growth, making the logical combination of these questions relevant for those interested in the intersection of politics and economics.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and could provide valuable insights into the potential future of both US politics and the automotive industry.

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, saying at a rally in March 2022, "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before". Early polling for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of June 2022), though Fox News producers have called him "the future of the Republican Party". DeSantis is a frequent second-place favorite in polling behind Trump.

Q.title: Will Any Major AI Company Commit to an AI Windfall Clause by 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any of the following companies/organizations ratifies a Windfall Clause before January 1, 2025:
Alphabet (or any of its subsidiaries, such as Deepmind or X)
Alibaba
Show More

metadata.background_info:
In 2020, the Future of Life Institute published a report entitled "The Windfall Clause: Distributing the Benefits of AI for the Common Good." (They also wrote an abridged version to be published in the Proceedings of AIES. Also, fun aside: Metaculus' own @Anthony got a shout-out in the acknowledgements.) Essentially, they expanded on an idea from Bostrom's Superintelligence that a firm working on transformational AI technology could limit global inequality as a result of their breakthrough by pre-committing to keep only a fraction of the fabulous profits, and distribute the rest.
Though there are numerous obstacles barring the path to making this plan a reality, the FLI research lowers many of these bars, including investigating the legal apparatus for enacting such an agreement and envisioning some of the logistical means by which a windfall might be distributed. What really remains is buy-in. If this plan will work, it will work because the companies positioned to develop windfall AI technologies signed on to a Windfall agreement in advance.
Show More

reasons: The political climate and leadership in the US can influence regulatory and policy decisions related to AI and technology companies. If Tucker Carlson becomes the Republican nominee, his stance on technology and AI regulation could impact the likelihood of major AI companies committing to an AI Windfall Clause.

The nomination of a high-profile political figure like Tucker Carlson could shift public discourse and priorities, potentially affecting corporate strategies and commitments, including those related to AI ethics and windfall clauses.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as political leadership can influence corporate behavior and regulatory environments.

P.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if before Janury 1 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung.
All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
Show More

Q.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to nuclear war?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In the headline question to this series, I defined a global catastrophe as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years.
If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of nuclear weapons?
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025 AND if a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to nuclear war?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. Before January 1, 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney, or lung. All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.

AND

2. In the event of a global catastrophe, defined as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years before 2100, it is principally due to the deployment of nuclear weapons.

The question resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if before Janury 1 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung.
All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
More than 30,000 organ transplants are performed each year in the United States alone, according to 2015 data from the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Around the world, the total was estimated to be 135,860 in 2016 according to the Global Observatory on Donation and Transplantation.
However, the demand for donor organs often significantly exceeds the supply, meaning that many patients have to wait for a significant period of time before receiving an acceptable donor organ. Many, tragically, die waiting.
In response to this problem, multiple efforts are underway around the world to create acceptable donor organs in laboratories. There have been reported successes for simpler tissue structures including vaginas, urethras, and bladders, but so far there have been no attempts in humans for hearts, livers, kidneys or lungs - though lab-grown lungs have been implanted into pigs and functional human “mini-kidneys” capable of filtering blood to produce urine have been grown in mice.
Show More

Q.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to nuclear war?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In the headline question to this series, I defined a global catastrophe as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years.
If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of nuclear weapons?
Show More

metadata.background_info:
You can now see an excellent visualization of global catastrophic risks estimates produced in the Ragnarök series here.
The invention of nuclear weapons gave humanity the technical capacity to cause devastation on a hitherto unseen scale. Although there have been no nuclear attacks since the Second World War, we have come close to inadvertent and intentional nuclear war on a number of occasions.
The Cuban Missile Crisis of October 1962 was a direct and dangerous confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cold War and was the moment when the two nuclear superpowers came closest to nuclear conflict. U.S. president John F. Kennedy estimated the odds of nuclear war at "somewhere between one out of three and even".
Show More

reasons: Technological advancements in medical science, such as the successful use of lab-grown organs, could be influenced by global stability. A nuclear war could disrupt scientific research and healthcare systems, delaying or preventing such advancements.

Conversely, the successful use of lab-grown organs could be seen as a sign of significant technological and societal progress, which might correlate with a lower likelihood of global catastrophes like nuclear war.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as global stability and technological advancements can be interrelated.

P.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques. "Gene editing techniques" means here CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception. This question will only include jurisdictions which govern a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect.
Show More

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Show More

P_and_Q.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered AND will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) Between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques, governing a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect, AND b.) the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.

P.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques. "Gene editing techniques" means here CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception. This question will only include jurisdictions which govern a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Our genes are the biologically encoded information from which we are built. Important traits known to be affected by our genes include aspects of intelligence and mental illness. Many physical traits, such as height, attractiveness, strength, and even longevity likewise strongly depend on the genes we have.
As the human genome and related human biological areas of inquiry became better understood, genetic engineering has become known. In the case of traits affected by simple genetic factors, it has been possible for years to change these genes, and the resulting trait(s) expressed, by means such as CRISPR/Cas9.
The pace of genetic engineering research, as measured by papers published worldwide, shows a clear trend to be growing. There is every reason to believe that as a result of this research trend, genetic engineering technology will tend to become safer, more powerful, and less expensive with time.
Show More

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Related Question on Metaculus:
Will the UK have a Conservative Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
The Labour Party is a centre-left political party in the United Kingdom that has been described as an alliance of social democrats, democratic socialists and trade unionists. The party's platform emphasises greater state intervention, social justice and strengthening workers' rights. As of 2020, it was last in power from 1997 to 2010.

P.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin.
Some crypto payment services work by exchanging the crypto for fiat at the point of transaction, and then sends fiat. That doesn't count -- what the IRS must receive and accept is the Bitcoin.
Show More

Q.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event. Statistical significance should be at the 4-sigma or equivalent level.
*(edit 1/1017) November 30 is now a publication date rather than data cutoff date.
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030 AND will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) At any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin. The IRS must receive and accept the Bitcoin, not through a service that exchanges crypto for fiat at the point of transaction. b.) By November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes with statistical significance at the 4-sigma or equivalent level. Resolves NO otherwise.

Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin.
Some crypto payment services work by exchanging the crypto for fiat at the point of transaction, and then sends fiat. That doesn't count -- what the IRS must receive and accept is the Bitcoin.

Q.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event. Statistical significance should be at the 4-sigma or equivalent level.
*(edit 1/1017) November 30 is now a publication date rather than data cutoff date.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
The Nobel Prize-winning detection of gravitational waves added a new observational tool for astronomers to use in studying celestial events. But an as-yet-unobserved phenomenon would make all the gravitational wave detections so far seem like small potatoes.
When two galaxies merge, the supermassive black holes at their centers would merge as well, and the process would emit gravitational waves. But the wavelength of those waves would be undetectable by the LIGO observatory. They're best detected by pulsar.
Pulsars emit electromagnetic radiation at regular intervals. A gravitational wave would slightly change the distance from the Earth to a pulsar, and thus slightly change the pulsar's timing as well.
In a paper in Nature Astronomy, astronomers use observation data and models of supermassive black hole merger events to conclude that we should be able to detect such an event within the next 10 years. If we don't, it could indicate that our .
Show More

P.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.
Related questions
Show More

Q.title: Will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the following criteria:

- The system must be open to the public and offer regular services.
- The system must cover a minimum distance of 50 miles between two or more stations.
- The system must be capable of achieving and sustaining speeds of at least 600 miles per hour during regular operation.
- The system must have completed all necessary safety inspections and received all required certifications from relevant U.S. regulatory bodies, such as the Department of Transportation and any state-level agencies involved.

In the event that multiple hyperloop systems become operational within the same time frame, the resolution will be based on the date of the first completed passenger journey.

If no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P_and_Q.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024 AND will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, AND b.) by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the specified criteria. The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team at the Olympics, or if no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date.

Related questions
Show More

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.
Related questions
Show More

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.
At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).
The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
Number of Gold Medals
(Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
(Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals
The US team is one of the most successful teams in recent Olympics, topping the medal table in 2020, 2016, 2012, 2004, 2000. Will they repeat that in 2024?
Show More

Q.title: Will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the following criteria:

- The system must be open to the public and offer regular services.
- The system must cover a minimum distance of 50 miles between two or more stations.
- The system must be capable of achieving and sustaining speeds of at least 600 miles per hour during regular operation.
- The system must have completed all necessary safety inspections and received all required certifications from relevant U.S. regulatory bodies, such as the Department of Transportation and any state-level agencies involved.

In the event that multiple hyperloop systems become operational within the same time frame, the resolution will be based on the date of the first completed passenger journey.

If no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
Show More

Q.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if before Janury 1 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung.
All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Ragnarok Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs due to an AI failure-mode AND lab-grown complex vital organs are used successfully in humans before 2025, will both be true?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: a.) A catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, AND b.) Any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung before January 1, 2025, with the transplantation considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
It resolves No if either of these conditions is not met, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs.

P.title: Ragnarök Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
You can now see an excellent visualization of global catastrophic risks estimates produced in the Ragnarök series here.
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
In a 2017 survey of artificial intelligence experts, the median expert estimated that there is a 50% chance of human-level artificial intelligence by 2062, and after this milestone were reached, respondents reported a 10% chance that superintelligence would be achieved within two years. Our very own question on the prospect of human-machine intelligence parity by 2040 currently has a median prediction of 60%. In another question on the possibility of progress toward human-machine intelligence parity surprising us, a similar median estimate is given.
Show More

Q.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if before Janury 1 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung.
All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
More than 30,000 organ transplants are performed each year in the United States alone, according to 2015 data from the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Around the world, the total was estimated to be 135,860 in 2016 according to the Global Observatory on Donation and Transplantation.
However, the demand for donor organs often significantly exceeds the supply, meaning that many patients have to wait for a significant period of time before receiving an acceptable donor organ. Many, tragically, die waiting.
In response to this problem, multiple efforts are underway around the world to create acceptable donor organs in laboratories. There have been reported successes for simpler tissue structures including vaginas, urethras, and bladders, but so far there have been no attempts in humans for hearts, livers, kidneys or lungs - though lab-grown lungs have been implanted into pigs and functional human “mini-kidneys” capable of filtering blood to produce urine have been grown in mice.
Show More

reasons: Both questions involve significant advancements in technology and their impacts on humanity.
A global catastrophe due to AI failure-mode could potentially accelerate or decelerate advancements in medical technology, including lab-grown organs.
The successful use of lab-grown organs could be seen as a marker of technological progress, which might correlate with the development and deployment of advanced AI systems.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they both pertain to the broader theme of technological impact on humanity.

P.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A positive resolution does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com in 2030, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.
Due to the nature of this question the best point optimizing prediction would be 99%, no matter of the real probability of Metaculus existing in 2030, as a non-existent Metaculus cannot make you lose points. Still, players are urged to predict in good faith

Q.title: Will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030 AND will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Metaculus:
A positive resolution requires a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.

Resolution Criteria for Earth Government:
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws.

The question resolves YES if both Metaculus exists in 2030 according to the specified criteria AND a single government governs 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A positive resolution does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com in 2030, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.
Due to the nature of this question the best point optimizing prediction would be 99%, no matter of the real probability of Metaculus existing in 2030, as a non-existent Metaculus cannot make you lose points. Still, players are urged to predict in good faith

metadata.background_info: Due to the fact that some of Metaculus' questions (and some of the most interesting/important ones for that) are extremely long-term, some users have expressed concern that Metaculus will not be around for resolution. While whether Metaculus will be around to resolve very long-term questions may not be of direct interest to predictors, as it does not really make sense to predict with points in mind if those points are decades away anyway, it would still be interesting to get a sense of what the probability is that Metaculus will be around in a couple of decades time.

Q.title: Will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations
Show More

metadata.background_info: China is currently the most populous county in the world, with 17.9% of the global population. Historically, only various Chinese empires and the Mongol and Roman Empires have exceeded 30% of the global population. This question asks if by 2100, there will be a centralised government ruling over 80% of the world's population, and accounting for over 80% of global GDP.

reasons: Metaculus is a platform for forecasting and predicting future events, and its existence in 2030 could be influenced by significant geopolitical changes, such as the emergence of a single global government.

A single government governing 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100 would be a monumental shift in global politics and economics, potentially affecting many aspects of society, including platforms like Metaculus.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is somewhat relevant because significant geopolitical changes could impact the existence of forecasting platforms like Metaculus.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Company valuations can take off very quickly: Apple was valued at around $100 billion in mid 2007, and so it has taken the company roughly 11 years to grow its market capitalisation by a factor of ten. However, one year before it first hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~$0.8 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question negative).
Show More

P_and_Q.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030 AND when the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

2. When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, it will be worth at least double what it was the year before. 

If either of these conditions is not met, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Company valuations can take off very quickly: Apple was valued at around $100 billion in mid 2007, and so it has taken the company roughly 11 years to grow its market capitalisation by a factor of ten. However, one year before it first hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~$0.8 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question negative).
Show More

reasons: Technological advancements and economic growth are often correlated. A successful manned mission to Mars by SpaceX could signify a period of rapid technological progress, which might also drive significant economic growth and market valuations.
SpaceX's success could boost investor confidence in technology companies, potentially accelerating the growth of market caps, including the first company to reach a $10 trillion market cap.
Elon Musk, the CEO of SpaceX, is also the CEO of Tesla, a company that could be a candidate for reaching a $10 trillion market cap. Success in one venture could positively influence the other.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, especially given the potential technological and economic impacts of a successful Mars mission.
